Evidence was split between plot‐ and catchment‐scale. Plot‐scale studies often included evaluations of engineered nature‐based solutions. At catchment‐scale, studies of streamwater quality typically investigated influence of contributory catchment nutrient sources. Canopy cover suppresses stream channel biological nitrogen uptake, which based on all evidence appears considerable. Using a discharge‐based relation, however, does not reflect the more fundamental dependence of channel geometry on basic watershed properties and precipitation characteristics. To explore relations between bankfull channel geometry and watershed properties, we consider two sets of dimensionless regression models: 1) with bankfull discharge as an independent variable, and 2) with bankfull discharge as a dependent variable. Abstract The transport of meltwater through porous snow is a fundamental process in hydrology that remains poorly understood but essential for more robust predictions of how the cryosphere will respond under climate change.
